review.title: A Brief History of Learning Classifier Systems: From CS-1 to XCS
review.abstract: Modern Learning Classifier Systems can be characterized by their use of rule accuracy as the utility metric for the search algorithm(s) discovering useful rules. Such searching typically takes place within the restricted space of co-active rules for efficiency. This paper gives an historical overview of the evolution of such systems.

metadata.title: A Brief History of Learning Classifier Systems: From CS-1 to XCS

sections.text: Accuracy as a utility measure for the search algorithm (the search algorithms) to discover useful rules. Such a search typically takes place within the limited framework of coactive efficiency rules. This paper provides a historical overview of the development of such systems.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The LCS formalism was introduced by John Holland [1976] and was based on his better known invention - the Genetic Algorithm (GA) [Holland, 1975]; a few years later, in collaboration with Judith Reitman, he presented the first implementation of an LCS in "Cognitive System Level 1" (CS-1) [Holland & Reitman, 1978]; Holland then revised the framework to define what would become the standard system for many years to come [Holland, 1980] but the full system of LCS was somewhat more complex and practical experience made it difficult to realize the intended behavior / performance of systems despite numerous modifications (e.g. Wilson S rule of 1989).

sections.heading: 2. The Evolution of Accuracy-based LCS
sections.text: In fact, most people who are able to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move and to move.

sections.heading: 2.3 GOFER
sections.text: The second LCS will therefore only receive a reward if it correctly exploits such categories in relation to the current task.

sections.heading: 2.7 Wilson’s XCS
sections.text: The main difference between XCS (Figure 5) and all other LCS prior to their presentation is that the suitability of the rule for the DG is not based on the level of the rules received, but purely on the accuracy of the predictions (p) of the reward. The intention in XCS is to build a complete and accurate representation of the problem area (rather than simply focusing on the higher payout levels in the environment) by efficient generalizations: XCS learns a value function across the entire government action space. A system prediction is then made for each action in [M] based on a weighted average of the predictions of the rules in all respects. The system action is then either deselected or randomly (usually 0.5 probability per attempt). If [M] is empty, the gain is used in XCS, which consists of three parameters, p and F for each corresponding rule.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusion
sections.text: The use of accuracy began with CS-1, although it was focused on the highest reward per niche. In addition, the generalization pressure of XCS has features that are consistent with that of CS-1, as it is also based on accuracy and usage rate. In CS-1, predicted rewards are only updated if they are accurate or below the current estimate, with measures and GA selection based on this parameter: more accurate rules are more likely to be reproduced. Rule periods are reset after use, and deletion is based on age: more frequently used rules are less likely to be replaced. Thus, CS-1 propagates more precise, more general (frequently applied) rules. XCS combines both accuracy in its pure form and frequency of use in GA selection processes.

Samuel [1959] described a scheme for adjusting temporally successive estimates of the end reward value from a sequence of moves (improved in [Samuel, 1967]).

The suggestion that a simulated evolutionary process may prove useful in artificial systems was first made by Turing [1948], with early implementations within a computer by Fraser [1957] and Box [1957].

A few years later Holland [1980] revised CS-1 and described what would become the standard architecture, here termed “Learning Classifier System” (LCS).

In particular, the idea that hierarchical rule associations could emerge via specific rules out-bidding more general rules in certain important situations, and extra “tag” regions of conditions and assertions being added would aid the formation of sequential induction (see [Holland et al., 1986] for a full treatment).
These ideas do not feature in modern LCS (see [Smith et al., 2010] for an exception).
The first of these, ANIMAT [Wilson, 1985], makes a number of simplifications to Holland’s architecture.

Results with ZCS indicated it was capable of good, but not optimal, performance [Wilson, 1994][Cliff & Ross, 1995]. Wilson [1994] also included a version of the offpolicy temporal difference learning algorithm Q-learning [Watkins, 1989] to some benefit.

Results with ZCS indicated it was capable of good, but not optimal, performance [Wilson, 1994][Cliff & Ross, 1995]. Wilson [1994] also included a version of the offpolicy temporal difference learning algorithm Q-learning [Watkins, 1989] to some benefit. He also proposed to use the triggered niche GA of GOFER on top of the panmictic/global scheme described above. Bull [2005] showed the potential for disruption of the reward sharing scheme using just a niche GA in a similar LCS but no combination is known.

Hartley [1999] showed NEWBOOLE to be competitive with XCS on a well-known set of binary classification tasks, although XCS’s maintenance of a full state-action-reward map gave it an advantage in some forms of non-stationary task (see [Bull & Hurst, 2002] for discussion).
Seemingly independently, Frey and Slate [1991] also presented a variant of BOOLE for supervised learning tasks in which they also update the correct set within [M] regardless of the output.

Seemingly independently, Frey and Slate [1991] also presented a variant of BOOLE for supervised learning tasks in which they also update the correct set within [M] regardless of the output. Having struggled to find the correct balance of taxing and bid biasing for a letter recognition task, with reference to Holland’s [1976] original ideas, they introduced the accuracy-utility system (here termed AU-BOOLE).
That is, Holland did not seek to change the rule structure from his standard LCS to this direct form. Riolo [1991] was first to implement lookahead capabilities within LCS with his CFSC2.

That is, Holland did not seek to change the rule structure from his standard LCS to this direct form. Riolo [1991] was first to implement lookahead capabilities within LCS with his CFSC2. He allowed the system to execute more than one cycle before providing an action, added tags along the lines Holland [1990] had suggested, and introduced an extra strength parameter to represent the predictive accuracy of a rule.
Roberts [1993] presented a related approach within ANIMAT which maintained “followsets”, time-stamped information regarding rewards received or next states obtained after a rule had fired.

A famous experiment with rats in a T-maze [Seward, 1949] is simulated and the results indicate similar behaviour from the ACS.
Stolzmann [1998] presented a system in which such a rule structure is used (the expecton component termed the “effect”) – the anticipatory classifier system (ACS).
The GA originally occurred in [M] but Wilson [1998] later move it to [A] to further reduce the potential for recombining rules inappropriately, i.
This has been studied formally and indicates the scalability of XCS’s learning mechanisms [Butz et al., 2004; 2007].

As mentioned above and shown in Figure 1, XCS and these key features have been extended beyond reinforcement learning to supervised [Bernado Mansiall & Garrell, 2003], unsupervised (clustering) [Tammee et al., 2007], function [Wilson, 2002] and model [Butz & Goldberg, 2003] learning.

metadata.abstractText: Modern Learning Classifier Systems can be characterized by their use of rule accuracy as the utility metric for the search algorithm(s) discovering useful rules. Such searching typically takes place within the restricted space of co-active rules for efficiency. This paper gives an historical overview of the evolution of such systems.
